interestingcomments.content: Does LR etc. apply demosaicing before displaying the raw file? Is there software that just shows the unaveraged pixel array?
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: Does LR etc. apply demosaicing before displaying the raw file? Is there software that just shows the unaveraged pixel array?

interestingcomments.content: It would make me dislike the programs even more 🥸. Are you sure that you have your import settings correct. They should include the sidecar and JPG files. Of course raw files display in colour. B&W raw files from a Bayer sensor always do. That is the reason that Leica provides DNG + JPG. If you want full quality raw monochrome raw files you should buy a Monochrom.
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: It would make me dislike the programs even more 🥸. Are you sure that you have your import settings correct. They should include the sidecar and JPG files. interestingcomments.content: 3 hours ago, jaapv said: It would make me dislike the programs even more 🥸. Are you sure that you have your import settings correct. They should include the sidecar and JPG files. Of course raw files display in colour. B&W raw files from a Bayer sensor always do. That is the reason that Leica provides DNG + JPG. If you want full quality raw monochrome raw files you should buy a Monochrom. I have to second this. interestingcomments.content: 26 minutes ago, pgk said: RAW file colour spaces are assigned so that they are processed and output into a specific colour space unless all colour management is turned off I think. That might indeed be the case for some raw converters, but for instance in Lightroom that doesn't show any difference to the raw file wether I set my camera to sRGB or Adobe RGB. Raw files are identical and can still be exported to any other colour space of choice in the export dialog. The only difference I have found is for in-camera jpg's which get assigned this colour space.
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: 26 minutes ago, pgk said: RAW file colour spaces are assigned so that they are processed and output into a specific colour space unless all colour management is turned off I think. Raw files are identical and can still be exported to any other colour space of choice in the export dialog. The only difference I have found is for in-camera jpg's which get assigned this colour space.

interestingcomments.content: 1 minute ago, SrMi said: The JPEG embedded in Q2's DNG file is a TIF with dimensions 8368 x 5584 (full size). P.S.: you can use ERawP application to extract the embedded JPEG. The JPEG is a TIFF? I think you meant there is simply a full-size JPEG embedded in the DNG, right?
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: 1 minute ago, SrMi said: The JPEG embedded in Q2's DNG file is a TIF with dimensions 8368 x 5584 (full size). P.S.: you can use ERawP application to extract the embedded JPEG. The JPEG is a TIFF? I think you meant there is simply a full-size JPEG embedded in the DNG, right?

interestingcomments.content: Correct. The B&W setting of the camera is JPG. A DNG file will always contain the full data, including colour, as it is not an image file.
interestingcomments.MarkedSent: Correct. The B&W setting of the camera is JPG. A DNG file will always contain the full data, including colour, as it is not an image file.
